tain knew you when you come to this country,

the Court to be divorced from his wife-but
when the case came up for trial, he was
unable to prove he ever had been married.

has been appointed post captain in the U.

Pennsylvania, from Pittsburgh, Steubenville
and Wheeling.

the Texel on the 18th of January, with
troops for Batavia, and was stranded on the
10th at Egmond She had on board about
1900 men. of whom about SO were lost.

Under the superintendent and instruction OF

THE course of instruction pursued at this sem
mary. comprises all the useful and most OF the
ornamental BRANCHES of female education, Inc
daily exercises are orthography, Reading' Writ
ing, Arithmetic, English Grammar, hhetoric'
Geography and History, ancient ana moaerh,
with constant reference to the best maps ana
charts; Construction of maps; use OF the 'iooes;
Natural History; Natural Philosophy, including
Astronomy and Chemstryi Elements OF Moral
Science. ~.
Itrekiy Exercise biblical Recitations; Evi.
dences OF Christianity; Letter Writing, ana otii-
er species of Composition; Iiecapitulations.
| IsrmS.--Boartl and tuition, i'll amy OF the fore
going branches, 332, so per quarter; or, IT PAID
| in advance. $50 Music, including the use OF a
piano, SD, French, by one of the best masters,
s. per quarter. Moderate extra charges Tor
! Drawing and other ornamental branches.


The discipline of the school is mild, parental,
and christian Particular attention IS paid not
only to the manners of the young ladies', but to
their moral and religious instruction they are
regularly conducted to such places OF worship
and Sunday Schools, as their parents and guar
dans approve. Exercise and recreation, oeihb
essential to the preservation OF heath ana OF
mental energy, occupy the Intervals OF ,,'ne i,ot
dey oted to study. The institution, in all its de-
partments, is conducted in a MANNER which 1t
Is hoped, will meet the entire appreciation OF its
patrons. ~ 80,

The Editor Of the Globe says: "rhe in
telligence in the Lisbon papers throws seme
additional light on the progress of the Por-
tugucse rebels, and of the measures taken to
resist them.


1T appears that after the fruitless attempt
on the bridge Of Amarante, and the crossing
of the Douro by the main body of the rebels,
near Lamego, the Marquis of Chaves adj
vanced to Vizeu. and placed himself in
communication with another corps, which
had previously occupied Guarda. Almeida
had, sometime previous to the 25th, fallen
into their hands. in consequence of the
treachery of the garrison. About the time
that the English troops landed i'll Portugal,
the affairs of the rebels seem to have begun
to decline. On the 23d of December they
seem to have not only been in undsturbed |
possession of the whole of Traz os-Montez,
but of great part of the adjoining province
of Beira. A line drawn from Chaves, on
the northern frontier, to Vizeu, and thence |
to the Spanish frontier, will describe the
limits of the rebels power, which extended
over nearly a.ffM fart of the surface of Por-
tugal. But about this time the troops OF
Gen. Claudino advanced towards Vizeu, to
Join the Constitutional forces under Azcrede;





had cleared the frontier south OF the Estrel-
| la, of the struggling parties which had en-
tered from Spain, marched upon Guarda,
out Of which he drove the rebels. On the
next day he marched forward, also in the
direction of Nizeu. by Celorie. so that the
rebels in Nizcu were threatened; by three
corps. According to the last intelligence,
they had left that town. fearing to be attack
ed, and had commenced their retreat.


sit is satisfactory that affairs had taken
this turn before the arrival OF the British
troops, as it shows that the disaffection to
the Constitution is far from being general
/ Though there had been much treachery and
dcsertions among the army, the Constitu-
tionalists have notiwanted faithful troops and
active leaders. From the notices which
reach us, the conduct of the Count de Villa
Flor (believe young oficer) appears 70
have been marked with great energy and
Judgment. After having thrown back the
rebels, who had attacked Villa Vicosa and


Estremos, into Spain, and completely secur-


ed the country south Of Tagus, he crossed
that river, advanced rapidly along the from


tier to the north, passed the chain OF the Es-
trella, which he also cleared OF some parties,


drove the rebels out of Guarda, and imme-
diately moving on Celorico, threatened the


rear of the Marquis of Chaves, and probably


determined his retreat. Under the clrcum-


stances of the season, the nature OF the cnun-
try, and the warfare which he has had to
contend, the movements seem to have been
J made with AS much rapdity as success.
! "The province of Mimic has continued Sc
! cure-few triAing attacks made on the north
,, part of the line of the remega having beer


repulsed with loss"

d Of the rebels.


r This unfortunate event is stated to hav
been owing partly to the illness OF Genera


Pogo, but principally to the dsloyal conaue
Is of the Col of the 10th regiment OF cayalr!
d and we greatly fear from the general con-
,e pexion Of the intelligence, that spirit
N dissatisfaction prcvades the corps.-lt is az
:. knowledged that some of the rebel bodit
NJ are we'll appointed, provided with StantS
r arms, and commanded by veteran ofhcers.-
J. 1t is even to be feared that the rebels, if the
d do not experience actual corporations, ;


least receive direct counteuance from IL
'e Spanish forces on the frontiers. The TO
it lowing package from the last despatch


the Marquis de Augeja, is far from presen


ing a favorable aspect Of affairs in that d
\, rcction ssthe regiments OF militia OF Il
~ province of Tras- Monies having repasst
rs the Douro, and the Guerillas being almo
h, as numerous as the population, the NOV
as ment of Gen. Mello could not be made wi
:. the rapidity that was desired. Col. lgnac
:. Perera, of the regiment Of Oreuse, has a
IS preached the frontier with his Guerilla
a where he saw great many Portuguese re
ok els in almost all the provinces OF Mimi
n some Spanish forces have also approach

the sheep Of a worthy miller. somewhere in
this COUNTY, are in danger Of beng all de-
vourcd by dogs and puppies, he has been
pleased to make known his fears and good
pleasure, by proclamation, wherein he de-
clares that a price shall be fixed on che head
Of every individual of the canine race, which
shall dare leap hedge, fence, or ditch, and
place paw on his lands. This grand bulletin,

determination against the long-tails, chanccd

RINGWooD'S LETTER TO DASH.


Near Roserilic, Feb 26, 1927


Dean DAsn-I have been SO much engaged
lately, fox hunting, that have neglected my old
correspondence with you but paper heard
read the other day puzzles Inc not al:tle-aitho'
am called as clever a dog at smelling out any
thing, as any in the country. 1t appeared, by
what could hear oft, (for the other dogs kept
up such an internal howling that had to prick
up my ears sharply that some mohSre's or ours
in the neighborhood of certain pretender to
law making and corn grinding, had killed sheep:
whcreupon, the law making miller issues ms
proclamation, offering reward of fifty cents for
the scalp of each and cutry dog killed on hisprem-
ises.


At first felt considerably alarmed lest we
were all doomed to die sheep killers death. -
But on hearing the latter part OF the paper read,
nv fears ceased as the miller iorbds all persons,
with or without dogs or guns, TO trespass on his





grounds, if neither men nor dogs dare go on
them-I should like to have your opinion on it,
though, as YOU pointers mix more in genteel So
ciety than we hounds do, and have parlor privi-
! lcges. There is another circumstance too, that
encourages me greatly: find, by listening to
my master and others, when reading newspa-
pers, that we dogs of the true breed, are rising
highly in the public estimation, especially in
Ncw-York; where great General, and no doubt
Il u 4 1z.l haaa 4 ltrl
in their councils, that dogs ought not to be tax-
cd-long may he live!! for should the law pass
that he has recommended, it will save many a
puppy's life, and prevent the hows of many q
bereavcd dogs nanny. would sugg"-. to you
that whenever this Legislative miller passes thro
your country, that you, and as many dogs OF your
acquaintance as can be suddenly assembled, sa
lutte him with real view hollow; for why should
we dogs of blood and good descent, be inciud
ed with ours and mongrels. As the partridge
season will soon be over, hope to sec you a
our place


Very Respectfully,-your long cared croney,


RINGWOOD.
| P. 8. understand that the dog eXtcrmlIiator
has never lost sheep, either by hound, pointer
or cur Of low degree; SO that his malice is per
fectly gratuitous.

nagcrs of St. Peters Church and VIM. Lar
kin, having undergone an examination ant
been laid before the public. we would sug
gest to The parties the propriety of suspend
ing further alteration. We believe quite a
much has been said, as it is proper shoul
. be expressed at this time; and since the cas-
has been submitted for judicial investigatio
and decision, further newspaper discussio
:: had better cease--particularly, as the par
f ties appear to be unable to confine them
d selves to the point IN question, and are lie
from 1t by disposition to indulge in lauguag
!. quite too acrimonious to reflect any cred
v upon the writer's.


It On Tuesday last. Mrs. Millgan. an ol
e and lonely woman. who has for many yea'
ID lived entirely by herself in this borough
j. was found lying in her house dead.-She WI


burnt to death. How this awful accidel


occ urred, no ono can exactly say; but it
,e supposed that whilst busy in preparing
al frugal meal for breakfast, her clothes tos
m fire, and before she could give the alarr
n she was killed by the flames.

,his fact that il it vas more convenient 10 yoli.
you would prefer the trustees and the quandam
were in Guinea. What did you do with the four
writs you had marked out against the four trus.
tees for scandalizing your character, by inform
ing the public that you held both pew rent, sub
scription and lottery money from the church,
oh, Billy, the public at large sees you delineat-
ed in your real colours. You swore that the
four trustees you took out writs against was for
leaving the state, or something to that effect
to prevent them of saying any thing more about
your honest transactions with the church. You
say YOU will not settle with the unprincipled
trlstees-you would prefer settling with some of
the backwoodsmen, whom you could tell tuf
tale to, and wash it down with gallon of whis-
key. Billy the trustees will never ask settle
ment from you again, the law must settle it now.
Billy, your friend, the quandam, sends his best
respects to you in cabbage leaf, to inform you
that the people who knew you where you come
from say that you were a man in public business,
and that your habitation was an exalted one
what the people in England calls Paddy's garret
or the first story below the pavement; and
that you was not inferior in your business to any
man in Dublin to give copel polish to pair of
boots or shoes, and the people that you are GER
tain knew you when you come to this country,
and know you still, say when you come here you
had the respectable appearance ofa Spittle-feld
weaver--that your dudds was tackled on you
with more pins than buttons. Billy, from your
respectable standing in society, we are not to
wonder at your barking like mastif dog at any


person who should attempt to bring you to JUS
tice, bnt your barking is useless. would not
give you UP to proaigacy, my dear Billy, for
bunch of matches Your devoted friend,


j PURCELL
N. B. Patrick Higgins has document Of
yours, which fully proves what you are.


March IA, 1927 26-4tp.

Der OF b!ack-icga in Anapolis immediately
decamped.


Four prisoners escaped from the Jail in
Flatbnsh, Long. Island, on the 14th ult. by
Knocking down the jailor; three of them
we're overtaken after a long chase, and the
fourth was discovered hid in barn.


A man in Exeter county, Mass. petitioned
the Court to be divorced from his wife-but
when the case came up for trial, he was
unable to prove he ever had been married.


Master commandant Joseph Nicholson,
has been appointed post captain in the U.
States Navy.


About $780, 900 worth of wool is trans
ported yearly, eastward into the interior Of
Pennsylvania, from Pittsburgh, Steubenville
and Wheeling.


The Dutch ~ Wascnaer, sailed from
the Texel on the 18th of January, with
troops for Batavia, and was stranded on the
10th at Egmond She had on board about
1900 men. of whom about SO were lost.

full articles.headline:
Young Ladies' Boarding School,


AT WILMINGTON, DELAWARE.
full articles.article:
Under the superintendent and instruction OF
WILLIAM SIIERER, assisted BY accomplished
female teachers.


THE course of instruction pursued at this sem
mary. comprises all the useful and most OF the
ornamental BRANCHES of female education, Inc
daily exercises are orthography, Reading' Writ
ing, Arithmetic, English Grammar, hhetoric'
Geography and History, ancient ana moaerh,
with constant reference to the best maps ana
charts; Construction of maps; use OF the 'iooes;
Natural History; Natural Philosophy, including
Astronomy and Chemstryi Elements OF Moral
Science. ~.
Itrekiy Exercise biblical Recitations; Evi.
dences OF Christianity; Letter Writing, ana otii-
er species of Composition; Iiecapitulations.
| IsrmS.--Boartl and tuition, i'll amy OF the fore
going branches, 332, so per quarter; or, IT PAID
| in advance. $50 Music, including the use OF a
piano, SD, French, by one of the best masters,
s. per quarter. Moderate extra charges Tor
! Drawing and other ornamental branches.


The discipline of the school is mild, parental,
and christian Particular attention IS paid not
only to the manners of the young ladies', but to
their moral and religious instruction they are
regularly conducted to such places OF worship
and Sunday Schools, as their parents and guar
dans approve. Exercise and recreation, oeihb
essential to the preservation OF heath ana OF
mental energy, occupy the Intervals OF ,,'ne i,ot
dey oted to study. The institution, in all its de-
partments, is conducted in a MANNER which 1t
Is hoped, will meet the entire appreciation OF its
patrons. ~ 80,

bert; Hon. w. Hall; Hon. Louis Ml.ahe: Fhifa
ac'phia--Rev. DIR. Wilson; Rev. DIR laneway

Thompson, Esq. Professor OF Languages YIN
versitv of Pennsylvania,

The Secretary at War, MIR. Barbour, has
written to Mr.. Powell, the Creek Agent.
and instructed him to ascertain whether the
Indians are willing to dispose of the strip
Of land within the limits of the State OF
Georgia, and at what price. The President
has resolved to purchase this land ifpossible,
as mean to end the dispute between hin.
and Gov 1'roup.

ior Griffin, died in Raleigh, N. c. on Wedncs-
day night last from the effects Of Intemperance.
"Some persons" says the Raleigh Register, cat
one of our tipping houses gave him, as we learn
a quart of liquor, on condition he wonld drink
the whole at one time. He succeeded in get
ting it down, and soon after fell into profound
sleep, from which he never awokci'

full articles.headline: FOREIGN xNTELLIGENCE.
full articles.article:
The Editor Of the Globe says: "rhe in
telligence in the Lisbon papers throws seme
additional light on the progress of the Por-
tugucse rebels, and of the measures taken to
resist them.


1T appears that after the fruitless attempt
on the bridge Of Amarante, and the crossing
of the Douro by the main body of the rebels,
near Lamego, the Marquis of Chaves adj
vanced to Vizeu. and placed himself in
communication with another corps, which
had previously occupied Guarda. Almeida
had, sometime previous to the 25th, fallen
into their hands. in consequence of the
treachery of the garrison. About the time
that the English troops landed i'll Portugal,
the affairs of the rebels seem to have begun
to decline. On the 23d of December they
seem to have not only been in undsturbed |
possession of the whole of Traz os-Montez,
but of great part of the adjoining province
of Beira. A line drawn from Chaves, on
the northern frontier, to Vizeu, and thence |
to the Spanish frontier, will describe the
limits of the rebels power, which extended
over nearly a.ffM fart of the surface of Por-
tugal. But about this time the troops OF
Gen. Claudino advanced towards Vizeu, to
Join the Constitutional forces under Azcrede;





had cleared the frontier south OF the Estrel-
| la, of the struggling parties which had en-
tered from Spain, marched upon Guarda,
out Of which he drove the rebels. On the
next day he marched forward, also in the
direction of Nizeu. by Celorie. so that the
rebels in Nizcu were threatened; by three
corps. According to the last intelligence,
they had left that town. fearing to be attack
ed, and had commenced their retreat.


sit is satisfactory that affairs had taken
this turn before the arrival OF the British
troops, as it shows that the disaffection to
the Constitution is far from being general
/ Though there had been much treachery and
dcsertions among the army, the Constitu-
tionalists have notiwanted faithful troops and
active leaders. From the notices which
reach us, the conduct of the Count de Villa
Flor (believe young oficer) appears 70
have been marked with great energy and
Judgment. After having thrown back the
rebels, who had attacked Villa Vicosa and


Estremos, into Spain, and completely secur-


ed the country south Of Tagus, he crossed
that river, advanced rapidly along the from


tier to the north, passed the chain OF the Es-
trella, which he also cleared OF some parties,


drove the rebels out of Guarda, and imme-
diately moving on Celorico, threatened the


rear of the Marquis of Chaves, and probably


determined his retreat. Under the clrcum-


stances of the season, the nature OF the cnun-
try, and the warfare which he has had to
contend, the movements seem to have been
J made with AS much rapdity as success.
! "The province of Mimic has continued Sc
! cure-few triAing attacks made on the north
,, part of the line of the remega having beer


repulsed with loss"


"London, Jan. IS.
, At late hour this morning, we received
Lisbon papers to the I'd inst The intelli
:, gcncc by this conveyance is interesting, tho
, not of decisive Importance. There is oihcIa
: intelligence of several actions having beer


fought between the Constitutional and Reb


cl forces. The rebel chief De Chaves ap
:. pears to have been at Visa on the 25th Dec
!. but subsequent accounts of the 9th inform
\, us that he was forced to retire from thence


his vanguard having previously plundere'


the town of Ieudelia We regret, however


to find in these official advices confirma
' ton of the accounts in the last French pa
= pers Of Almeda having fallen into the hand
d Of the rebels.


r This unfortunate event is stated to hav
been owing partly to the illness OF Genera


Pogo, but principally to the dsloyal conaue
Is of the Col of the 10th regiment OF cayalr!
d and we greatly fear from the general con-
,e pexion Of the intelligence, that spirit
N dissatisfaction prcvades the corps.-lt is az
:. knowledged that some of the rebel bodit
NJ are we'll appointed, provided with StantS
r arms, and commanded by veteran ofhcers.-
J. 1t is even to be feared that the rebels, if the
d do not experience actual corporations, ;


least receive direct counteuance from IL
'e Spanish forces on the frontiers. The TO
it lowing package from the last despatch


the Marquis de Augeja, is far from presen


ing a favorable aspect Of affairs in that d
\, rcction ssthe regiments OF militia OF Il
~ province of Tras- Monies having repasst
rs the Douro, and the Guerillas being almo
h, as numerous as the population, the NOV
as ment of Gen. Mello could not be made wi
:. the rapidity that was desired. Col. lgnac
:. Perera, of the regiment Of Oreuse, has a
IS preached the frontier with his Guerilla
a where he saw great many Portuguese re
ok els in almost all the provinces OF Mimi
n some Spanish forces have also approach
" the frontiers of the same province"

It having appeared by proclamation. that
the sheep Of a worthy miller. somewhere in
this COUNTY, are in danger Of beng all de-
vourcd by dogs and puppies, he has been
pleased to make known his fears and good
pleasure, by proclamation, wherein he de-
clares that a price shall be fixed on che head
Of every individual of the canine race, which
shall dare leap hedge, fence, or ditch, and
place paw on his lands. This grand bulletin,
announcing the commencement of war OF
determination against the long-tails, chanccd
to be read in the hearing of one of the
hopeared kind; he becomes alarmed tor
the safety ofaH concerned, and writes to one
of the more privileged class for advice in
the matter; and for more general circulation
the printer is honored with a copy OF the let

Academy, and Emmanuel Church.

witness our hands, at Wilmington, tins i4th

am not ignorant that 500 multiplied by
500 produces 25e,o00; and that If a sells 3
q Mat of ground to be covered over with dol
!, nc or cents. as the case may be, the num-
hor o5o 600 is correct. Because, in this case,
though the rule is arbitrary, it serves the
nurpose intended. 1t is arbitrary TOR tins
resson--diyision is substituted where the
sums to be multiplied amount to tens, hun
dreds, &c. Sometimes We prepare our num-
hers by division. previous to multiplying,
vet this may be done as well after as be-
fore I need not enter into detailed ac-
count concerning what is familiar to most,
otherwise than to introduce the subject that
am called upon to explain.


"F." writer in late number of the
Wilmingtonian, appears to accuse me with
propoundng question that ! cannot ex-
plain, which is, the multiplying certain
number of dollars, dimes, cents, and mills
in such way as to mark out their value
Now, in the first place, / wish it to be un,
derstood that in the example alluded to,
made use of no multiplication whatever
neither had to resor. to any other figure!
in finding the result, than part of the re-
suit itself, which part enabled me to find tht
other part simply by subtraction. Some
think that multiplication and subtraction arr
antipodes--how can that be, when they pro
duce the same result? was in hopes som,
critic, say "F." would have answered m.
request in explaining the method Iuse, ra
than to have called in question the merits o
the question itself; yet seeing no way Il
creep out, ] will not desert my post:--sup
pose then we multiply

unproductivc wilderness.

to be read in the hearing of one of the
flopeared kind; he becomes alarmed for
the safety of all concerned, and writes to one
of the more privileged class for advice in
the matter; and for more general circulation
the printer is honored with acopy of the let
ter.


RINGWooD'S LETTER TO DASH.


Near Roserilic, Feb 26, 1927


Dean DAsn-I have been SO much engaged
lately, fox hunting, that have neglected my old
correspondence with you but paper heard
read the other day puzzles Inc not al:tle-aitho'
am called as clever a dog at smelling out any
thing, as any in the country. 1t appeared, by
what could hear oft, (for the other dogs kept
up such an internal howling that had to prick
up my ears sharply that some mohSre's or ours
in the neighborhood of certain pretender to
law making and corn grinding, had killed sheep:
whcreupon, the law making miller issues ms
proclamation, offering reward of fifty cents for
the scalp of each and cutry dog killed on hisprem-
ises.


At first felt considerably alarmed lest we
were all doomed to die sheep killers death. -
But on hearing the latter part OF the paper read,
nv fears ceased as the miller iorbds all persons,
with or without dogs or guns, TO trespass on his





grounds, if neither men nor dogs dare go on
them-I should like to have your opinion on it,
though, as YOU pointers mix more in genteel So
ciety than we hounds do, and have parlor privi-
! lcges. There is another circumstance too, that
encourages me greatly: find, by listening to
my master and others, when reading newspa-
pers, that we dogs of the true breed, are rising
highly in the public estimation, especially in
Ncw-York; where great General, and no doubt
Il u 4 1z.l haaa 4 ltrl
in their councils, that dogs ought not to be tax-
cd-long may he live!! for should the law pass
that he has recommended, it will save many a
puppy's life, and prevent the hows of many q
bereavcd dogs nanny. would sugg"-. to you
that whenever this Legislative miller passes thro
your country, that you, and as many dogs OF your
acquaintance as can be suddenly assembled, sa
lutte him with real view hollow; for why should
we dogs of blood and good descent, be inciud
ed with ours and mongrels. As the partridge
season will soon be over, hope to sec you a
our place


Very Respectfully,-your long cared croney,


RINGWOOD.
| P. 8. understand that the dog eXtcrmlIiator
has never lost sheep, either by hound, pointer
or cur Of low degree; SO that his malice is per
fectly gratuitous.


The subject of dispute, between the Ma
nagcrs of St. Peters Church and VIM. Lar
kin, having undergone an examination ant
been laid before the public. we would sug
gest to The parties the propriety of suspend
ing further alteration. We believe quite a
much has been said, as it is proper shoul
. be expressed at this time; and since the cas-
has been submitted for judicial investigatio
and decision, further newspaper discussio
:: had better cease--particularly, as the par
f ties appear to be unable to confine them
d selves to the point IN question, and are lie
from 1t by disposition to indulge in lauguag
!. quite too acrimonious to reflect any cred
v upon the writer's.


It On Tuesday last. Mrs. Millgan. an ol
e and lonely woman. who has for many yea'
ID lived entirely by herself in this borough
j. was found lying in her house dead.-She WI


burnt to death. How this awful accidel


occ urred, no ono can exactly say; but it
,e supposed that whilst busy in preparing
al frugal meal for breakfast, her clothes tos
m fire, and before she could give the alarr
n she was killed by the flames.
I'd --
